THE NEWS LETTER
BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 1, 1911.

VOL. XV, No. 26.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

DEBATE A TIE

INTEnSTATE CONTEST HERE

HOPKINS AGAIN

COMMENCEMENT ARRANGEMENTS

The Negative Team Wins in Each of
the Three Contests on Last
Friday Night.

College Orators From Seven States Will
Engage in Notable Competition
on Friday Evening.

The Much-Vaunted Swarthmore Team
Succumbs to Our Lacrosse Experts -- A Great Contest.

President Noble of Goucher College Will
Make the Address--Exercises in
the Academy of Music.

The first appearance of a Hopkins debating team at Gettysburg
on last Friday night was marked by
a victory, which opens auspiciously
the series of contests between the
two institutions. The debate was
held in Brua Chapel and was presided over by Prof. P. M. Bikle,
Ph. D., who read the regulations
governing the affair and introduced
the speakers.
For Gettysburg Messrs. C. M.
Davis and E. J. Bowman spoke in
affirmation of the question: "Resolved, That the present distribution of powers between the Federal
and State governments should be
revised in accordance with a general policy of further centralization." The . negative • was maintained by W. 0. Weyforth and T.
B. Price for Johns Hopkins.
Music was furnished during the
intermissions by the college orchestra. The judges were Dr. B. 0.
McIntyre, Prof. U. S. Steele and
Dr. W. D. Rorer.
The speakers for the, affirmative
both presented very strong arguments, which were to a large extent
entirely different from those offered
by the affirmative in the recent interclass debate in McCoy Hall. Mr.
Davis in particular, though excelled
by his colleague in delivery, made
a very strong and thoughtful
speech, involving some rather intricate political reasoning. In reply,
Mr. Weyforth contended that a policy of centralization was entirely
unnecessary, while Mr. Price took
the position that it was decidedly
undesirable. Great credit is due the
former for the excellent showing
he made, in view of the fact that he
had less than a week in which to
prepare the whole subject.
Following the set speeches, which
were . . each twenty minutes in
length, each man spoke briefly in
rebuttal. Hopkins scored here by
attacking the general nature of the
affirmative's debate and calling for
specific instances in which a policy
of centralization would help the nation.
At the conclusion of the program
Professor Bikle spared the feelings
of both speakers and audience by
announcing the decision•in favor of
the negative without the usual long
preamble.. The debate Was generally considered to have been extremely close, but the decision of
the judges was accepted by the partisans of GettYsburg in a graceful
fashion.

As a special session of the Third
National Peace Congress, the fifth
annual interstate oratorical contest
of the Intercollegiate Peace Assorciation will be held in McCoy Hall,
Friday, May 5, at 8.15 P. M. At
the same time the banquet of the
Congress will take place at the Belvedere Hotel; but as the number of
subscriptions to the banquet is limited, it is not thought that this function will materially interfere with
the attendance at McCoy Hall.
The contest will be in charge .of
the Intercollegiate Peace Association, which offers two prizes, $75
and $50, for first and second honors, respectively. The President of
the Association, Dean William P.
Rodgers, of the Cincinnati Law
School,is expected to preside. There
will be sevei. contestants, representing the seven States of Wisconsin,
Michigan, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio,
Pennsylvania, and Maryland. Each
of these contestants.has this spring
won the oratorical contest held betWeen the colleges of his own State.
These seven men have been chosen
as the best out of about 300 orators, representing seventy-five colleges, so that the orations to be delivered Friday evening promise to
be highly meritorious.
The details of the contest are being arranged by the Johns Hopkins
Arbitration Society, co-operating
with the University and the officials
of. the Peace Congress. Invitations
issued by the University will be
distributed early in the week, and
it is hoped that the members of the
University will feel responsible for
giving as much publicity as possible
to the contest. Five prominent
men of Baltimore and vicinity have
consented to act as judges. The
public is invited .10 attend. The
speakers, with their States, colleges
and subjects, are as folldivs
Wisconsin—C. L. Saxby, Beloit
College, "The Evolution of Peace."
Michigan—Stanley H. Howe, Albion College,"The Hope of Peace."
Illinois -Wayne Calhoun, Illinois
Wesleyan University,"V Tar and the
Man."
Indiana—Charles M. Anderson,
University of Notre Dame, "America and Universal Peace."
Pennsylvania — C. M. Lodge,
Dickinson • College, "The Proposed
Court of Arbitral.Justice."
Marylandr-Lingurn B. Bobbitt,
Johns Hopkins University, "Patriotism • and Peace."
Ohio—(Representative not yet
rel)Orted).

In one of the best lacrosse games
played this year Hopkins won from
the Swarthmore twelve on Saturday by a score of I I to 7. The final
score does not indicate the intensity
of the contest, for the score was
evened up four times during the
game.
Every member of the team should
be given full credit, for they all
showed true grit and skill. Stockett, Captain Hulburt and Gail
starred on the close attack; Bennie
Kline and Wolfe were invincible in
the midfield, and G. Schmeisser,
Hopkins and Gillet were most aggressive on the defense. Perkins,
Mesner, P. Roberts, and C. Collins
starred for Swarthmore.
- Swarthmore was unnecessarily
rough at times and lost no opportunity to whack a Hopkins man
across the head. Luckily, only one
Hopkins man was injured, and that
was Benedict, who suffered a nasty
scalp wound from a blow that cut
through the thickest part of his padded cap. Benedict pluckily continued in the game.
Captain Hulburt scored first blood
for Hopkins when he slipped in a
tricky low one past Goalkeeper Atkinson. Wolfe made the second
tally by beautiful individual work,
when he ran two-thirds the length
of the field, dodging the entire
Swarthmore defense and shooting
goal.
With two goals registered for
Hopkins, the ire of the Swarthmore attack was aroused and they
started one of their famous Canadian-style onslaughts. P. Roberts,
their experienced inhome, snapped
in their first tally. The first half
ended with the score 4 to 4.
Hopkins started out with the first
tally in the second session, which
was due to the clever work of
Stockett. This nimble first attack,
after missing a low shot, caught the
quick return from behind the net
and dropped the -ball in the net
without the Swarthmore goaltender
so much as moving.
The score continued to see-saw
back and forth in the second session. But with one marvelous
burst of.energy Hopkins scored six
goals in rapid succession and put
the game on ice. The line-up:
Hopkins—Sutton, g.; Schmeisser,
p.; Niles, cp.; Benedict, id.; Hopkins, 2d.; Gillet, 3d.; Wolfe, c.;
Tappan and Gail, 3a.'; Kline, 2a.;

The exercises of the thirty-fifth
annual commencement will be held
at the Academy of Music on Tuesday, June 13, at 4 o'clock. President Noble, of Goucher College,
will be the speaker.
There will be the usual procession, headed by President Remsen
and the speaker, which will assemble in McCoy Hall. The medical students, the candidates for the
doctor of philosophy degree, and
the candidates for bachelor of arts,
will follow in the order named.
The selection of Dr. Noble as
speaker comes as a surprise. It is
the first time in many years that a
Baltimore man has spoken at the
commencement, and hence the address will be one of particular intereSt to Baltimoreans.

Hopkins Juniors Lose.

The Baltimore City College defeated the Johns Hopkins University Juniors at lacrosse on Wednesday, at Homewood, 2 to 0.
The collegians played an excellent
game against superior weight and
swiftness that exceeded theirs, and
pulled out of many holes in a remarkable manner.
• Considerable amusement was
caused by the playing of Knipp, the
four-foot in-home of the collegians,
against Price, of Hopkins, who is
over six feet tall. Knipp played a
swift game, and, being small of
stature, he was able to get around
his man time after time.
Pyles shot the first goal in the
first half, and Troxell put the second ball in the net during the second half in a pass over the net. The
Wilson brothels, Wolfe and Knipp
starred for the winners. H. Burgall, Chesney, and Musser played
the best game for Hopkins. The

It is now but six weeks until the
close of the academic year and there
are 125 subscriptions which are unpaid. What this means to us is obvious when it is considered that the
printer must be paid by June. Such
laxity is unpardonable and we
should not have to refer continually
to the delinquents in this column,
and it is clearly impossible for the
business manager to speak with
every subscriber individually. Everyone who subscribed should feel it a
disgrace to allow his bill to remain
unpaid throughout the year.

HORRAX STARS AGAIN

LEFRANC & AULT

One Year of Collegiate Latin
Study to Be Required in
Group III.

Just Nosed Out at the Tape in the
Hurdles and Gets Third in
the Broad Jump.

During the Past week the Board
of Collegiate Studies has arrived at
the definite determination to shorten
requirements in collegiate Latin for
the men in the historical and political science group (Group III)
from two years to one year. The
step, though generally disapproved,
is felt to be necessary to maintain
the usefulness of the group, whose
membership has fallen off 6o per
cent, during the last five years. A
large partof this decrease is thought
to be directly due to the requirements in Latin, which many men
preferred to avoid by entering one
of the scientific groups. Whether,
however, this is the real reason for
the popularity of the latter groups,
whether the change will produce
any material ,effect, and what will
be the result of the anti-classical
tendency that it evinces in this day
when a reaction against anti-classicism seems about to set in, are questions which must be answered by
the future.

Horrax came up to the expectations of his supporters at the Pennsylvania meet in Philadelphia
,on
Saturday. He finished second in
the I20-yard hurdle and got third
place in the broad jump. The hurdle race was one of the most interesting on the program. Horrax
qualified in the third heat, finishing
second to Edwards, of Pennsylvania, who holds the world's record
for this event of 15 1-5 seconds. In
the second semi-final he beat Chisholm, of Yale, in 16 seconds. The
final was won by Chisholm in 15 4-5
seconds, just a nose ahead of Horrax. The field was one of the best
ever in competition, including
Dwight, of Princeton, who finished
third ;Meyers, of Indiana State Normal; Stibolt, of Cornell; Fletcher,
of Notre Dame; Whiting and
Kuhn, of Chicago, and Havens, of
Rutgers.
The second of Horrax's performances was his broad jump of 22
feet Y2 inch. This event was won
by J. Wasson, of Notre Dame, with
a jump of 23 feet 3 inches. Mercer, of Pennsylvania, was second.
The mile relay, in which Hopkins
competed, was won by Fordham in
3:32 1-5. New York University
was second and Hopkins third.
Chicago University won the mile
relay championship in 3:21, while
Pennsylvania got the two-mile relay and then lost the four-mile
championship to Cornell. Notre
Dame won the honors as the individual point winner.

University of Pennsylvania recently held a circus and hippo(ironic, in which 300 students took
part.

An exceeding erudite and philosophic lecture was delivered in McCoy Hall last Tuesday afternoon by
Prof. James W. Bright, of the English department. Dr. Bright's subject was "The Authenticity of Po=
etry," or an examination into the
causes which give poetry a claim
upon the attention of man. The lecture was well attended.
Lecture by Professor Robinson.

Tomori ow afternoon at 5 o'clock
Dr. David M. Robinson, associate
professor of classical archeology in
the University, will give an illustrated lecture on "Ruined Cities of
Asia Minor." This is the first time
in two years that Dr. Robinson will
be heard in a public lecture at the
University. Last year (19o9-191o)
he was professor of Greek in the
American School of Classical Studies at Athens.

Professor Moore, of Columbia, Delivers
Four Very Interesting "Foundation" Lectures.
Every student who has not heard
the lectures of Dr. Moore, of Columbia, on "The Schouler Foundation" has missed hearing four very
interesting lectures. In the first lecture Dr. Moore said that the love of
liberty, the directness of action and
the confidence of power possessed
by the American colonies induced
them to throw off the commercial
restrictions which England imposed
on them. The causes which brought
about a feeling of unity among the
colonies were the publication of
Paine's "Common Sense," a fiery
appeal to unity, and the fact that
as a nation we prepared to ask
Spain and France to help its against
England if Portugal captured our
ships. The four courses that induced our fathers in the Constitution to break down the sovereignty
of the States were: (I) In the
Treaty of Paris, England ceded to
us a great deal of land which belonged to no one State;(2) the central government guaranteed by the
Treaty of Paris that citizens within
the States would pay the debts
which they owed Englishmen; (3)
without greater federalization than
was provided for in the Articles of
Confederation we could not defend
our frontiers or establish national
credit; and the most important factor of all, our commerce, was continually extending.
In the second lecture Dr. Moore
pointed out some effect of the wave
of Democracy which has swept over
our country. On this wave were
borne such reforms as the taking
the right of nominating candidates
for the Presidency from the small
body of electors and giving the
right to popular conventions, the
breaking down of religious and
property' qualifications for voters
and the popular election. of Federal
judges. The democratic attitude
of the people is shown by the resolutions in favor of the independence
of Greece and other countries
which they forced Congress to pass.
In his third lecture Dr. Moore
gave it as his opinion that the imperialistic period of our history began when, disregarding the Constitution, Lincoln was given the
powers of a dictator. After the
Civil War it was impossible for the
States to bear as independent a relation to the central government as
they had borne before; on the contrary, imperialism, on account of
our growing interstate commerce
and the needs of our national life,
has been gaining ground.
Dr. Moore, in his concluding lecture, said that in the march across
the Continent, the American people
have been actuated by a belief that
by manifest destiny a united people
like ours should possess a united
country. But not only North America, but South America and the
whole world are a united country;
so one might think that manifest

destiny has just begun to shower
blessings upon us. Of the land outside of America which we have annexed, a part, which we could not
get by treaty, we took by legislation; and when our sense of missionary duty has not been strong
enough to induce us to annex new
land our sense of commercial advantage usually has been.
Phi Beta Kappa Banquet.
Arrangements for the annual
banquet of the Baltimore Chapter
of Phi Beta Kappa, which is to be
held Saturday, May 6, are being
completed by Prof. Murray P.
Brush, chairman of the committee.
Before the banquet an election will
be held for the selection of new
members, the honor men of the senior class. The result of the election is awaited with curiosity.
DEBATE A TIE
(Continued from page 1.)
The Hopkins visitors were entertained on Saturday by a most interesting trip over the battle field of
Gettysburg and were shown every
courtesy by their hosts.
The debate between Washington
and Lee and Johns Hopkins, the
former supporting the negative, the
latter the affirmative side of the
question, was won by the visitors.
It was the first time in many
years that a Hopkins debating team
went down to defeat. The judges,
Judge Heuisler and Judge Bond, of
the Baltimore city bench, and Mr.
Eugene O'Dunne, of the Baltimore
bar, were, however, not unanimous
in their decision.
Mr. Bobbitt, of Johns Hopkins,
the first speaker of the affirmative,
opened the debate. He contended
that could the affirmative show that
functions of substantial importance
now exercised by the individual
States should be entrusted to the
Federal Government then the affirmative would have proved its
case; and he devoted his speech to
the exposition of certain evils which
have grown up under State control
of corporations, labor organizations,
child labor, conservation, etc., and
to an examination into the reasons
why the individual States are fundamentally unable to remedy these
evils.
Mr. Babbitt was followed by the
first speaker of the negative, Mr. J.
C. Herndon, whose speech consisted
of an enumeration of the constitutional powers of the central government and of the functions which
under these powers that government can exercise.
The second speaker of the affirmative, Mr. Leo Wolman, continued the arguments of Mr. Bobbitt and explained why in a great
variety of matters the national government is better qualified to be
the repository of power than the
State governments. He also maintained that the transference of all
problems which become national in
importance to Federal control,

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 1, 1911

HOLIDAY LACROSSE GAMES

HOPKINS LOSES BASEBALL GAME

Varsity Adds Three Games to Its String
of Victories by Defeating Cornell, Harvard and Carlisle.

Western Maryland Wins Easily From
Black and Blue—Two Home
Runs Are Made.

On April 8 the Varsity defeated
Cornell with ease by the score of
8 to 2. The team played one of the
best games so far, as was shown by
the way the attack men were working together, and they had no trouble in scoring goals on the Northern team.
On April 15 the Varsity defeated
Harvard by a close score-3 to 2.
Although the score was close, Hopkins did not have much trouble in
defeating them. The game was all
Hopkins from the start, and the
boys wanted to save themselves for
the following Saturday,. when they
played the Indians, one of the best
teams in the country.
On April 22, with a great shock
to the Indians and much surprise
to the spectators, Hopkins walked
away with the game by the score of
8 to 5. The game was not an easy
one by any means, but the Black
and Blue boys won, and that was all
they wanted. The game was a
fight from start to finish. Although
the game was rough, none of the
Hopkins men were hurt. Sutton
stopped shot after shot which
seemed a sure goal. The mid-field
men worked beautifully together for
the first time this year. . One of the
Indians had his arm broken in some
mysterious manner.

Much to the surprise of the large
crowd of spectators who went to
Homewood last Saturday afternoon, the Hopkins baseball team received a severe trouncing at the
hands of the Western Maryland
nine. The score was 9 to 2. Hopkins was not only beaten, but badly
beaten, and partly because of ragged playing.
The up-State boys played an errorless game and deserved to win.
Twigg was very effective in the
box, allowing only four hits, and he
received excellent support from his
team mates.
The Western Maryland players
touched up Silvester, the Hopkins
twirler, for thirteen hits. Stultz, the
first batter up, swatted the first ball
thrown for a clean single. Sprague.
bunted safely, Stultz going to second. Stultz scored on a wild throw
to first of Graefe's easy grounder.
Sprague was nailed at the plate in
attempting to run home after Webster had caught Dooley's fly. Graefe
scored on a passed ball.
Western Maryland scored two
more runs in the fourth inning,
when Beall knocked the ball over
the right-field fence into the boulevard for a home run with Meyer on
first.
Hopkins made its only runs in the
second half of the fourth inning.

From May 3-5, in McCoy Hall,
the Third National Peace Conference will meet. At both the First
National Peace Conference, held in
New York in 1907, and the Second, held in Chicago in 1909, the
audiences were large and much interest was shown. The conference
will be held in Baltimore this year,
so that the South may be drawn
more fully into the peace movement.
The Congress -will deal with two
leading lines of peace work: (I)
The awakening of public conscience
by addresses directed against the
folly and injustice which flow from
war, together with the economic
waste of universal armaments, and
( 2) the practical'means of making
\var difficult by establishing institutions which will take away the excuse for making war."
Active and influential men will
attend the Congress and endeavor
to make the conference a success
and to push forward the cause of
peace. President Taft himself will
open the first meeting at 2 P. M.
Wednesday. He is expected to
speak on "Arbitration Courts."
Count Tolstoi, the son of the famous Russian, was expected, but
he had to leave America before the
meetings could • take place. The
University of Pennsylvania sends
perhaps the greatest of our national
authorities on the Latin-American
States in the person of Prof. Leo
S. Rowe. The most celebrated foreigners attending will be Baron de
Constant of France, who was a delegate to the second Hague Conference, and Henri La Fontaine, a Belgian, the president of the International Peace Bureau. The reoresentative of the oriental world will
be Dr. T. Tvrenage, the Japanese
lecturer at the University of Chicago. Miss Belva Lockwood, the
well-known woman peace advocate.
together . with Miss Fannie Fern
Andrews, the Secretary of the
American School Peace League,
will take prominent parts in the
conference.
. The Rt. Hon. James Bryce will
• probably preside on the afternoon
of May 5. On the same evening, at
7 o'clock, the congress will close
with a banquet at the Belvedere.

THE NEWS LETTER
BALTIMORE, MD., MAY 1, 1911.

VOL. XV, No. 26.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

DEBATE A TIE

INTEnSTATE CONTEST HERE

HOPKINS AGAIN

COMMENCEMENT ARRANGEMENTS

The Negative Team Wins in Each of
the Three Contests on Last
Friday Night.

College Orators From Seven States Will
Engage in Notable Competition
on Friday Evening.

The Much-Vaunted Swarthmore Team
Succumbs to Our Lacrosse Experts -- A Great Contest.

President Noble of Goucher College Will
Make the Address--Exercises in
the Academy of Music.

The first appearance of a Hopkins debating team at Gettysburg
on last Friday night was marked by
a victory, which opens auspiciously
the series of contests between the
two institutions. The debate was
held in Brua Chapel and was presided over by Prof. P. M. Bikle,
Ph. D., who read the regulations
governing the affair and introduced
the speakers.
For Gettysburg Messrs. C. M.
Davis and E. J. Bowman spoke in
affirmation of the question: "Resolved, That the present distribution of powers between the Federal
and State governments should be
revised in accordance with a general policy of further centralization." The . negative • was maintained by W. 0. Weyforth and T.
B. Price for Johns Hopkins.
Music was furnished during the
intermissions by the college orchestra. The judges were Dr. B. 0.
McIntyre, Prof. U. S. Steele and
Dr. W. D. Rorer.
The speakers for the, affirmative
both presented very strong arguments, which were to a large extent
entirely different from those offered
by the affirmative in the recent interclass debate in McCoy Hall. Mr.
Davis in particular, though excelled
by his colleague in delivery, made
a very strong and thoughtful
speech, involving some rather intricate political reasoning. In reply,
Mr. Weyforth contended that a policy of centralization was entirely
unnecessary, while Mr. Price took
the position that it was decidedly
undesirable. Great credit is due the
former for the excellent showing
he made, in view of the fact that he
had less than a week in which to
prepare the whole subject.
Following the set speeches, which
were . . each twenty minutes in
length, each man spoke briefly in
rebuttal. Hopkins scored here by
attacking the general nature of the
affirmative's debate and calling for
specific instances in which a policy
of centralization would help the nation.
At the conclusion of the program
Professor Bikle spared the feelings
of both speakers and audience by
announcing the decision•in favor of
the negative without the usual long
preamble.. The debate Was generally considered to have been extremely close, but the decision of
the judges was accepted by the partisans of GettYsburg in a graceful
fashion.

As a special session of the Third
National Peace Congress, the fifth
annual interstate oratorical contest
of the Intercollegiate Peace Assorciation will be held in McCoy Hall,
Friday, May 5, at 8.15 P. M. At
the same time the banquet of the
Congress will take place at the Belvedere Hotel; but as the number of
subscriptions to the banquet is limited, it is not thought that this function will materially interfere with
the attendance at McCoy Hall.
The contest will be in charge .of
the Intercollegiate Peace Association, which offers two prizes, $75
and $50, for first and second honors, respectively. The President of
the Association, Dean William P.
Rodgers, of the Cincinnati Law
School,is expected to preside. There
will be sevei. contestants, representing the seven States of Wisconsin,
Michigan, Illinois, Indiana, Ohio,
Pennsylvania, and Maryland. Each
of these contestants.has this spring
won the oratorical contest held betWeen the colleges of his own State.
These seven men have been chosen
as the best out of about 300 orators, representing seventy-five colleges, so that the orations to be delivered Friday evening promise to
be highly meritorious.
The details of the contest are being arranged by the Johns Hopkins
Arbitration Society, co-operating
with the University and the officials
of. the Peace Congress. Invitations
issued by the University will be
distributed early in the week, and
it is hoped that the members of the
University will feel responsible for
giving as much publicity as possible
to the contest. Five prominent
men of Baltimore and vicinity have
consented to act as judges. The
public is invited .10 attend. The
speakers, with their States, colleges
and subjects, are as folldivs
Wisconsin—C. L. Saxby, Beloit
College, "The Evolution of Peace."
Michigan—Stanley H. Howe, Albion College,"The Hope of Peace."

In one of the best lacrosse games
played this year Hopkins won from
the Swarthmore twelve on Saturday by a score of I I to 7. The final
score does not indicate the intensity
of the contest, for the score was
evened up four times during the
game.
Every member of the team should
be given full credit, for they all
showed true grit and skill. Stockett, Captain Hulburt and Gail
starred on the close attack; Bennie
Kline and Wolfe were invincible in
the midfield, and G. Schmeisser,
Hopkins and Gillet were most aggressive on the defense. Perkins,
Mesner, P. Roberts, and C. Collins
starred for Swarthmore.
- Swarthmore was unnecessarily
rough at times and lost no opportunity to whack a Hopkins man
across the head. Luckily, only one
Hopkins man was injured, and that
was Benedict, who suffered a nasty
scalp wound from a blow that cut
through the thickest part of his padded cap. Benedict pluckily continued in the game.
Captain Hulburt scored first blood
for Hopkins when he slipped in a
tricky low one past Goalkeeper Atkinson. Wolfe made the second
tally by beautiful individual work,
when he ran two-thirds the length
of the field, dodging the entire
Swarthmore defense and shooting
goal.
With two goals registered for
Hopkins, the ire of the Swarthmore attack was aroused and they
started one of their famous Canadian-style onslaughts. P. Roberts,
their experienced inhome, snapped
in their first tally. The first half
ended with the score 4 to 4.
Hopkins started out with the first
tally in the second session, which
was due to the clever work of
Stockett. This nimble first attack,
after missing a low shot, caught the
quick return from behind the net
and dropped the -ball in the net
without the Swarthmore goaltender
so much as moving.
The score continued to see-saw
back and forth in the second session. But with one marvelous
burst of.energy Hopkins scored six
goals in rapid succession and put
the game on ice. The line-up:
Hopkins—Sutton, g.; Schmeisser,
p.; Niles, cp.; Benedict, id.; Hopkins, 2d.; Gillet, 3d.; Wolfe, c.;
Tappan and Gail, 3a.'; Kline, 2a.;

The exercises of the thirty-fifth
annual commencement will be held
at the Academy of Music on Tuesday, June 13, at 4 o'clock. President Noble, of Goucher College,
will be the speaker.
There will be the usual procession, headed by President Remsen
and the speaker, which will assemble in McCoy Hall. The medical students, the candidates for the
doctor of philosophy degree, and
the candidates for bachelor of arts,
will follow in the order named.
The selection of Dr. Noble as
speaker comes as a surprise. It is
the first time in many years that a
Baltimore man has spoken at the
commencement, and hence the address will be one of particular intereSt to Baltimoreans.

Hopkins Juniors Lose.

The Baltimore City College defeated the Johns Hopkins University Juniors at lacrosse on Wednesday, at Homewood, 2 to 0.
The collegians played an excellent
game against superior weight and
swiftness that exceeded theirs, and
pulled out of many holes in a remarkable manner.
• Considerable amusement was
caused by the playing of Knipp, the
four-foot in-home of the collegians,
against Price, of Hopkins, who is
over six feet tall. Knipp played a
swift game, and, being small of
stature, he was able to get around
his man time after time.
Pyles shot the first goal in the
first half, and Troxell put the second ball in the net during the second half in a pass over the net. The
Wilson brothels, Wolfe and Knipp
starred for the winners. H. Burgall, Chesney, and Musser played
the best game for Hopkins. The

HORRAX STARS AGAIN

LEFRANC & AULT

One Year of Collegiate Latin
Study to Be Required in
Group III.

Just Nosed Out at the Tape in the
Hurdles and Gets Third in
the Broad Jump.

During the Past week the Board
of Collegiate Studies has arrived at
the definite determination to shorten
requirements in collegiate Latin for
the men in the historical and political science group (Group III)
from two years to one year. The
step, though generally disapproved,
is felt to be necessary to maintain
the usefulness of the group, whose
membership has fallen off 6o per
cent, during the last five years. A
large partof this decrease is thought
to be directly due to the requirements in Latin, which many men
preferred to avoid by entering one
of the scientific groups. Whether,
however, this is the real reason for
the popularity of the latter groups,
whether the change will produce
any material ,effect, and what will
be the result of the anti-classical
tendency that it evinces in this day
when a reaction against anti-classicism seems about to set in, are questions which must be answered by
the future.

Horrax came up to the expectations of his supporters at the Pennsylvania meet in Philadelphia
,on
Saturday. He finished second in
the I20-yard hurdle and got third
place in the broad jump. The hurdle race was one of the most interesting on the program. Horrax
qualified in the third heat, finishing
second to Edwards, of Pennsylvania, who holds the world's record
for this event of 15 1-5 seconds. In
the second semi-final he beat Chisholm, of Yale, in 16 seconds. The
final was won by Chisholm in 15 4-5
seconds, just a nose ahead of Horrax. The field was one of the best
ever in competition, including
Dwight, of Princeton, who finished
third ;Meyers, of Indiana State Normal; Stibolt, of Cornell; Fletcher,
of Notre Dame; Whiting and
Kuhn, of Chicago, and Havens, of
Rutgers.
The second of Horrax's performances was his broad jump of 22
feet Y2 inch. This event was won
by J. Wasson, of Notre Dame, with
a jump of 23 feet 3 inches. Mercer, of Pennsylvania, was second.
The mile relay, in which Hopkins
competed, was won by Fordham in
3:32 1-5. New York University
was second and Hopkins third.
Chicago University won the mile
relay championship in 3:21, while
Pennsylvania got the two-mile relay and then lost the four-mile
championship to Cornell. Notre
Dame won the honors as the individual point winner.

Professor Moore, of Columbia, Delivers
Four Very Interesting "Foundation" Lectures.
Every student who has not heard
the lectures of Dr. Moore, of Columbia, on "The Schouler Foundation" has missed hearing four very
interesting lectures. In the first lecture Dr. Moore said that the love of
liberty, the directness of action and
the confidence of power possessed
by the American colonies induced
them to throw off the commercial
restrictions which England imposed
on them. The causes which brought
about a feeling of unity among the
colonies were the publication of
Paine's "Common Sense," a fiery
appeal to unity, and the fact that
as a nation we prepared to ask
Spain and France to help its against
England if Portugal captured our
ships. The four courses that induced our fathers in the Constitution to break down the sovereignty
of the States were: (I) In the
Treaty of Paris, England ceded to
us a great deal of land which belonged to no one State;(2) the central government guaranteed by the
Treaty of Paris that citizens within
the States would pay the debts
which they owed Englishmen; (3)
without greater federalization than
was provided for in the Articles of
Confederation we could not defend
our frontiers or establish national
credit; and the most important factor of all, our commerce, was continually extending.
In the second lecture Dr. Moore
pointed out some effect of the wave
of Democracy which has swept over
our country. On this wave were
borne such reforms as the taking
the right of nominating candidates
for the Presidency from the small
body of electors and giving the
right to popular conventions, the
breaking down of religious and
property' qualifications for voters
and the popular election. of Federal
judges. The democratic attitude
of the people is shown by the resolutions in favor of the independence
of Greece and other countries
which they forced Congress to pass.
In his third lecture Dr. Moore
gave it as his opinion that the imperialistic period of our history began when, disregarding the Constitution, Lincoln was given the
powers of a dictator. After the
Civil War it was impossible for the
States to bear as independent a relation to the central government as
they had borne before; on the contrary, imperialism, on account of
our growing interstate commerce
and the needs of our national life,
has been gaining ground.
Dr. Moore, in his concluding lecture, said that in the march across
the Continent, the American people
have been actuated by a belief that
by manifest destiny a united people
like ours should possess a united
country. But not only North America, but South America and the
whole world are a united country;
so one might think that manifest

destiny has just begun to shower
blessings upon us. Of the land outside of America which we have annexed, a part, which we could not
get by treaty, we took by legislation; and when our sense of missionary duty has not been strong
enough to induce us to annex new
land our sense of commercial advantage usually has been.

DEBATE A TIE
(Continued from page 1.)
The Hopkins visitors were entertained on Saturday by a most interesting trip over the battle field of
Gettysburg and were shown every
courtesy by their hosts.
The debate between Washington
and Lee and Johns Hopkins, the
former supporting the negative, the
latter the affirmative side of the
question, was won by the visitors.
It was the first time in many
years that a Hopkins debating team
went down to defeat. The judges,
Judge Heuisler and Judge Bond, of
the Baltimore city bench, and Mr.
Eugene O'Dunne, of the Baltimore
bar, were, however, not unanimous
in their decision.
Mr. Bobbitt, of Johns Hopkins,
the first speaker of the affirmative,
opened the debate. He contended
that could the affirmative show that
functions of substantial importance
now exercised by the individual
States should be entrusted to the
Federal Government then the affirmative would have proved its
case; and he devoted his speech to
the exposition of certain evils which
have grown up under State control
of corporations, labor organizations,
child labor, conservation, etc., and
to an examination into the reasons
why the individual States are fundamentally unable to remedy these
evils.
Mr. Babbitt was followed by the
first speaker of the negative, Mr. J.
C. Herndon, whose speech consisted
of an enumeration of the constitutional powers of the central government and of the functions which
under these powers that government can exercise.
The second speaker of the affirmative, Mr. Leo Wolman, continued the arguments of Mr. Bobbitt and explained why in a great
variety of matters the national government is better qualified to be
the repository of power than the
State governments. He also maintained that the transference of all
problems which become national in
importance to Federal control,

THE NEWS-LETTER, MAY 1, 1911

HOLIDAY LACROSSE GAMES

HOPKINS LOSES BASEBALL GAME

Varsity Adds Three Games to Its String
of Victories by Defeating Cornell, Harvard and Carlisle.

Western Maryland Wins Easily From
Black and Blue—Two Home
Runs Are Made.

On April 8 the Varsity defeated
Cornell with ease by the score of
8 to 2. The team played one of the
best games so far, as was shown by
the way the attack men were working together, and they had no trouble in scoring goals on the Northern team.
On April 15 the Varsity defeated
Harvard by a close score-3 to 2.
Although the score was close, Hopkins did not have much trouble in
defeating them. The game was all
Hopkins from the start, and the
boys wanted to save themselves for
the following Saturday,. when they
played the Indians, one of the best
teams in the country.
On April 22, with a great shock
to the Indians and much surprise
to the spectators, Hopkins walked
away with the game by the score of
8 to 5. The game was not an easy
one by any means, but the Black
and Blue boys won, and that was all
they wanted. The game was a
fight from start to finish. Although
the game was rough, none of the
Hopkins men were hurt. Sutton
stopped shot after shot which
seemed a sure goal. The mid-field
men worked beautifully together for
the first time this year. . One of the
Indians had his arm broken in some
mysterious manner.

Much to the surprise of the large
crowd of spectators who went to
Homewood last Saturday afternoon, the Hopkins baseball team received a severe trouncing at the
hands of the Western Maryland
nine. The score was 9 to 2. Hopkins was not only beaten, but badly
beaten, and partly because of ragged playing.
The up-State boys played an errorless game and deserved to win.
Twigg was very effective in the
box, allowing only four hits, and he
received excellent support from his
team mates.
The Western Maryland players
touched up Silvester, the Hopkins
twirler, for thirteen hits. Stultz, the
first batter up, swatted the first ball
thrown for a clean single. Sprague.
bunted safely, Stultz going to second. Stultz scored on a wild throw
to first of Graefe's easy grounder.
Sprague was nailed at the plate in
attempting to run home after Webster had caught Dooley's fly. Graefe
scored on a passed ball.
Western Maryland scored two
more runs in the fourth inning,
when Beall knocked the ball over
the right-field fence into the boulevard for a home run with Meyer on
first.
Hopkins made its only runs in the
second half of the fourth inning.

From May 3-5, in McCoy Hall,
the Third National Peace Conference will meet. At both the First
National Peace Conference, held in
New York in 1907, and the Second, held in Chicago in 1909, the
audiences were large and much interest was shown. The conference
will be held in Baltimore this year,
so that the South may be drawn
more fully into the peace movement.
The Congress -will deal with two
leading lines of peace work: (I)
The awakening of public conscience
by addresses directed against the
folly and injustice which flow from
war, together with the economic
waste of universal armaments, and
( 2) the practical'means of making
\var difficult by establishing institutions which will take away the excuse for making war."
Active and influential men will
attend the Congress and endeavor
to make the conference a success
and to push forward the cause of
peace. President Taft himself will
open the first meeting at 2 P. M.
Wednesday. He is expected to
speak on "Arbitration Courts."
Count Tolstoi, the son of the famous Russian, was expected, but
he had to leave America before the
meetings could • take place. The
University of Pennsylvania sends
perhaps the greatest of our national
authorities on the Latin-American
States in the person of Prof. Leo
S. Rowe. The most celebrated foreigners attending will be Baron de
Constant of France, who was a delegate to the second Hague Conference, and Henri La Fontaine, a Belgian, the president of the International Peace Bureau. The reoresentative of the oriental world will
be Dr. T. Tvrenage, the Japanese
lecturer at the University of Chicago. Miss Belva Lockwood, the
well-known woman peace advocate.
together . with Miss Fannie Fern
Andrews, the Secretary of the
American School Peace League,
will take prominent parts in the
conference.
. The Rt. Hon. James Bryce will
• probably preside on the afternoon
of May 5. On the same evening, at
7 o'clock, the congress will close
with a banquet at the Belvedere.
